articles.headline: Disney Hopes New (and Nostalgic) Formula Will Draw Tweens
articles.snippet: In “Girl Meets World,” Disney Channel tries to strip away Internet conventions.
articles.abstract: In “Girl Meets World,” Disney Channel tries to strip away Internet conventions.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Disney Channel has a history of serving up programming that defines pop culture for pre-teenage girls: “Lizzie McGuire,” “Hannah Montana,” “Wizards of Waverly Place,” “High School Musical.” But that cable network has not found a new live-action juggernaut in years and its overall ratings are declining.

articles.headline: Larry Page on Google’s Many Arms
articles.snippet: For a company whose future depends on people handing over their information in return for handy online services, Google’s very ambitions may now stand as its biggest hurdle.
articles.abstract: For a company whose future depends on people handing over their information in return for handy online services, Google’s very ambitions may now stand as its biggest hurdle.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One way to think of Google is as an extremely helpful, all-knowing, hyper-intelligent executive assistant. Already, it can remind you about your flight, open up your boarding pass when you get to the airport and offer you driving directions to your hotel when you land.

articles.headline: Stalemate Over Garment Factory Safety in Bangladesh
articles.snippet: In several cases where hazardous conditions were uncovered, there has been considerable resistance to closing a factory, as owners worry about losing orders and workers fear losing their jobs.
articles.abstract: In several cases where hazardous conditions were uncovered, there has been considerable resistance to closing a factory, as owners worry about losing orders and workers fear losing their jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eight times now, the European-dominated Accord on Fire and Building Safety in Bangladesh — a group of more than 150 retailers and brands — has forced the temporary closing of garment factories after its inspectors found dangerous conditions.
articles.byline: By Steven Greenhouse and Julfikar Ali Manik

articles.headline: G.M. Halts Sale of Cruze Sedan Over Takata Air Bags
articles.snippet: The car company says the mechanics of the air bags may be faulty, causing improper inflation.
articles.abstract: The car company says the mechanics of the air bags may be faulty, causing improper inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Motors ordered dealers to stop selling the 2013 and 2014 versions of its most popular car, the Chevrolet Cruze sedan, because of a problem with air bags made by the Japanese supplier Takata, whose products are already the subject of a large recall of other vehicles.
articles.byline: By Aaron M. Kessler and Christopher Jensen

articles.headline: In a U.S. Court, Iraqis Accuse Blackwater of Killings in 2007
articles.snippet: More than four dozen Iraqi citizens are scheduled to travel to Washington to testify against the Americans who they say fired wildly on unarmed citizens, leaving 17 Iraqis dead.
articles.abstract: More than four dozen Iraqi citizens are scheduled to travel to Washington to testify against the Americans who they say fired wildly on unarmed citizens, leaving 17 Iraqis dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The witness wore a suit with no tie, the top button of his gray shirt undone. He had told this story many times, and now that he was in the United States, telling his story at last to a jury, he appeared neither hurried nor anxious.

articles.headline: Blacks Regain Sway at Polls in Mississippi
articles.snippet: African-American voters are hoping to flex political muscles long atrophied after supporting Senator Thad Cochran on Tuesday in his runoff victory against a Tea Party challenger.
articles.abstract: African-American voters are hoping to flex political muscles long atrophied after supporting Senator Thad Cochran on Tuesday in his runoff victory against a Tea Party challenger.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — For the first time since President Richard M. Nixon’s divisive “Southern strategy” that sent whites to the Republican Party and blacks to the Democrats, African-American voters have come out in force for a Republican in the Deep South.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: Shiite Violence Traps Baghdad’s Sunnis, Haunted by a Grim Past
articles.snippet: Sunnis fear that walls built by the Americans to protect them could also entrap them, making them easy prey for emboldened Shiite militias who executed Sunnis in large numbers not many years ago.
articles.abstract: Sunnis fear that walls built by the Americans to protect them could also entrap them, making them easy prey for emboldened Shiite militias who executed Sunnis in large numbers not many years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The bodies arrive in twos and threes most every day in the Baghdad morgue now, a grim barometer of the city’s sectarian tensions. Most have gunshot wounds to the head, some have signs of torture, and most of them are Sunnis.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Rod Nordland

articles.headline: Court Rejects Zone to Buffer Abortion Clinic
articles.snippet: The unanimous decision struck down a Massachusetts law enacted in 2007 that created 35-foot buffer zones around entrances to abortion clinics.
articles.abstract: The unanimous decision struck down a Massachusetts law enacted in 2007 that created 35-foot buffer zones around entrances to abortion clinics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday unanimously  struck down a Massachusetts law that barred protests, counseling and other speech near abortion clinics.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and John Schwartz

articles.headline: Supreme Court Rebukes Obama on Right of Appointment
articles.snippet: The justices ruled that President Obama had violated the Constitution when he appointed officials to the National Labor Relations Board during a brief Senate break.
articles.abstract: The justices ruled that President Obama had violated the Constitution when he appointed officials to the National Labor Relations Board during a brief Senate break.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court issued a unanimous rebuke to President Obama on Thursday, saying he had overreached in issuing recess appointments during brief breaks in the Senate’s work.
